item.title: Open a pull-request to GitHub from the CLI
item.description: After spending some time getting git pull-request to work I decided it was to much of a hassle and would try to make my own function. If you are on OS X, drop the following in your .bashrc or your preferred $SHELL equivalent and source it: function git_pull_request() { REPOURL=`git config --get remote.origin.url` REPO=`basename -s .git $REPOURL` BRANCH=`git symbolic-ref -q --short HEAD` GIT_USER=`git config user.name` if [[ -z $GIT_USER ]] then echo "Please set your Git user name by running: git config --global user.

item.title: Generate .gitignore from the command line
item.description: You can generate .gitignore files from the command line by using the api of gitignore.io. To do this you need to create a git alias. git config --global alias.ignore \ '!gi() { curl -sL https://www.gitignore.io/api/$@ ;}; gi' When you created the alias you have access to the git ignore command. If you run git ignore list you will get a list of supported languages, tools, os’s and applications. For example, running git ignore python,visualstudiocode,osx will dump a list of ignored files for Python, VSCode and OS X to stdout.
